Anyway, seems like a case of "patches welcome", and if it looks reasonable it'll probably get merged.

note.body: I think nowadays the Xsettings daemon dependency can be dropped from a Wayland session on all circumstances. Xwayland on demand is the default in Mutter these days, so this daemon is not required at session startup.

Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body:
Without reading the ticket, I can already tell you that there is nothing needed on the GNOME side. You *can* already do this by executing "loginctl unlock-sessions". The infrastructure is there, you just need to implement and launch a small daemon inside the user session.

Any such implementation would not be part of gnome-session.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body:
> I've recently had my laptop stolen, and my password is not so strong.

Strong passwords for disk encryption don't require to "type such a password all day long", it's only once when booting.

> But it could be other external auth method like usb key

Things like Yubikeys exist.

> Taking a step forward and thinking about how passwordless auth could be is not so dumb IMO.

I agree. But that's not what this ticket is about. This ticket says "unlock with my phone". Which is a (wrong) "solution" in search of a problem. You may want to discuss this further in https://discourse.gnome.org because "using a phone" per se does not solve any problem with your laptop.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body:
> Because your phone also has an unlock password. There is zero advantage

Of course there is. You're phone is unlocked by shemas or with what ever see fit (with better biometric hardware that most PC). And it's real **quick**. there is no such feat on PC. Nor password recovery mechanism.

I've recently had my laptop stolen, and my password is not so strong. And there is no way to remote reset your laptop. I should have put some 16+ characters password. But it would not be convenient to type such a password all day long.

But it could be other external auth method like usb key (but usb key with physical contact is meehhh). And again passwords are something that will disappear at some point. Taking a step forward and thinking about how passwordless auth could be is not so dumb IMO.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone
Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body: Because your phone also has an unlock password. There is zero advantage. So you propose to enter a password on a different device, and then have more work to open an app for some QR code.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body:
> Many machines have fingerprint readers now

not mine sorry, using old thinkpads. and not reliable (I'm doing lot of cooking and always washing my hands, finger prints never last long)

> QR code scanning or TOTP is usually a Two Factor Authentication

Steam Guard is using QR code for authentication (but it's just a lead not a solution)

It's not a "problem" and I've no "solution". It's for convenience. Typing strong password is really not so easy. Especially if you have many computers. So the point is (and it's not my point, it's a tendency to use phone for authentication 1 step or many steps, passwords will be somethig of the past at one point or another): why not use something we always have, our phones, to open/unlock session ? If it's dumb, it's dumb and sorry for the noise... But at least KDEConnect creators find this usefull.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

note.body: Hi, I don't understand which problem this "solution" is supposed to solve. Many machines have fingerprint readers nowadays. QR code scanning or TOTP is usually a Two Factor Authentication, not replacing passwords for now. Could you please elaborate about the actual problem? Thanks.

target_title: Adding feature like open session/unlock with my phone

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body: What I don't understand is: why is this reported against gnome-session instead of pipewire?

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body:
I tried waiting in gdm for:

* ~5 sec - snapshots fails ("No camera found")
* ~10 sec - snapshot works

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body:
@rmader hmm, where you maybe logged in over ssh at the same time, or logged into a VT?

If you have no sessions running for your normal user then the associated "systemd --user" process should shutdown all associated services and then shut itself down after some timeout.

Also if you have stuff running under tmux/screen as your user then that will typically also stop the "systemd --user" session from terminating and this keep any services associated with that session alive.

Maybe you have enabled lingering for your user, e.g. you have run `sudo loginctl enable-linger $USER` at some point?

Unfortunately there is no way to check the state for this, but you can make sure it is disabled by running `sudo loginctl disable-linger $USER`

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body: This unfortunately doesn't seem to restart it. I just tested on a device with clean Fedora 41 (+testing), once waiting in gdm for two minutes and once till the device went into suspend. In both cases the service was still active when logging in again - and the portal/cameras didn't work.

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body: What happens if you wait say 1 minute between "logout" and "login again" ?

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body:
On my setups STR step 2 is non-mandatory, it fails too if:

0. reboot
1. log into Gnome
2. logout
3. login again
4. try to start Snapshot

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body: I'm not familiar with the portal code so I have no suggestions on what may be causing this issue.

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body: Hm, that would explain why it's not an issue for sound. Any thoughts why the portal would have issues connecting though?

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout

note.body:
pipewire not exiting is expected behavior, pipewire is not started as part of the gnome-session but as part of the user systemd "session", e.g. it will also get started if you login on a VT with the user.

The systemd user session will timeout if the gnome-session was the only active session underneath it and then pipewire will get terminated.

It seems to me that this needs to be fixed in the portal and the portal needs to learn to deal with re-using the pipewire instance.

target_title: Some user services like Pipewire do not get terminated on logout
gnome-session wrapper: Avoid running as a subprocess

push_data.commit_title: gnome-session wrapper: Avoid running as a subprocess

target_title: gnome-session wrapper: Avoid running as a subprocess

note.body:
I think this was probably not noticed in distributions like Fedora where `/bin/sh` is bash because bash has the implementation detail that it optimizes a simple command like `bash -c 'foo bar'` by behaving as though the command had been `bash -c 'exec foo bar'` (the `bash` process is replaced by the `foo` process).

But on the Debian distribution family, `/bin/sh` is usually dash, a minimal POSIX shell which does not have that optimization.

push_data.commit_title: gnome-session wrapper: Avoid running as a subprocess

target_title: Wayland session crashes when adding an X11 system tray icon
Wayland session crashes when adding an X11 system tray icon

note.body:
Right, gnome-shell is aborting with SIGTRAP. But I suppose the bug is more likely inside libmutter. Moving there for a start. Even if the tray icon might not be working, it shouldn't be crashing.

If you have the journal information, it would be useful to know what gnome-shell logged. Check `journalctl --user -u org.gnome.Shell@wayland.service`. There is probably some `CRITICAL` warning.

EDIT: Or well, you might even be able to get a backtrace using `coredumpctl`.

target_title: Wayland session crashes when adding an X11 system tray icon
